Input.threadtitle: Why doesn't BTB contain both target address and target instruction?
Input.posts:
Why doesn't the BTB contain both the target address and target instruction? Wouldn't this save 1 cycle if the branch is correctly predicted taken and make it truly 0 cycle penalty? The BTB as described in Professor David course contains the target address and Branch address, I guess if the current PC address matches the contents of BTB/Br address, it is defined as taken although a more complex scheme could also involve the PTH and BHR in the model of BTB. Anyway, if you draw some timing, you can see the following: BTB as in the course, i.e. No instruction target in the BTB leads to: \xA0 \xA0 cycle#1 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 Cycle#2 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Cycle#3 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Cycle#4 \xA0 \xA0 Cycle#5 F\xA0 \xA0Br_addr \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 Tar_addr D \xA0\xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Br_instr \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Tar_instr E \xA0\xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Br_Cond \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Tar_instr W \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 Tar_instr This is in its simplest form a 4 stage pipelines. As you can see, in cycle#1, the PC contains the branch address, and it is compared w/ the corresponding BTB entry and if being equal => PC contents points to a branch instruction in iCache.\xA0in cycle #2 it contains the target address, in cycle#3 it reads the Target instruction out of the iCache, etc. Now considering BTB including both the instruction target and address target, and branch predicted taken: \xA0 \xA0 cycle#1 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Cycle#2 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Cycle#3 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Cycle#4 F\xA0 \xA0Br_addr \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 Tar_addr+4 D \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 Tar_instr, Br_instr E \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Br_Cond,\xA0Tar_instr\xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 W \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0 \xA0Tar_instr In cycle#1, all happens as in the previous simpler BTB case (no instruction target). In cycle#2 and at Fetch stage ( F ), the PC now contains the Target address + 4, the target instruction is also going directly to the decode stage as is the branch instruction itself (2 decode reg). This obviously requires more read ports on the RF, so perhaps this is good for the super-scalar 2-issue which has 4 read ports. It also implies that the Branch when in exe has its own circuitry to perform the condition and assess whether the instruction was indeed correctly predicted taken while the Target instruction is also executing its operation. The later case, finishes one cycle earlier than the case where the BTB contains only the target address. Conditional branches are usually non intrusive, therefore should not change the register file. This saves one cycle, whether it is worth, perhaps only in the case of >= 2-issues. In single pipeline, cost of adding 2 register R ports may be too high and return on investment too low when putting the average branch rate, the correctly predicted taken, the ratio of non taken v.s. taken. In case of super-scalar, the cost is minimum.

This does seem possible. \xA0I am not sure why you have the target instruction and the branch executing concurrently. \xA0You could just have the target instruction follow the branch instruction and avoid all the overheads you mentioned. \xA0However, there are other tricks for removing the one cycle penalty. \xA0You could pre-decode conditional branches in the fetch stage and do branch prediction in the fetch stage, in which case you would know the target PC as the branch enters the decode stage and could begin fetching the target instruction such that there is no bubble in the pipeline. \xA0There are probably other methods for removing the penalty as well. \xA0Your idea seems as though it could work as well. \xA0 However, if you think about it, branches are usually about 10% of the instructions in a program. \xA0If you save one cycle on branches, you are improving CPI by 0.1. \xA0Thus, it may not be worth the additional complexity for a small improvement in performance. \xA0Ultimately, this is up to the designer to make the trade-off decision.

Input.threadtitle: L18S5 : In MESI protocol how does a Snoopy Cache determine if a Cache line is shared or not ( I state to E/S state ) ?
Input.posts:
For the MESI protocol, a transition from I to S is made when there is a 'Read Miss, Shared'. On the right side, the different shaded boxes indicate whether the processor is busy or waiting due to some reason ( ICache/Dcache miss etc. ). \xA0If a 'processor busy' is defined as a state where the processor is executing an instruction, then all the other boxes should indicate that the processor is Idle due to some reason. Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The original paper the graph is from, which is cited on the slide, explains 'processor busy represents utilized issue slots; all others represent wasted cycles' \xA0I think short int, long int, short fp, and long fp may be due to data hazards, i.e. an issue slot could not be used because instructions were waiting on results from a short int, long int, short fp, or long fp instruction. \xA0I am not positive about this, but the main takeaway is that many functional units are underutilized in a superscalar processor. \xA0It is essentially motivating multithreading by saying many functional units are under utilized and switching in other threads on stalls could hide some of this latency.

Input.threadtitle: L15S6 : Slide Deck 12 Slide 22.  What  do the bars of the Short int long int short fp and long fp signify?
Input.posts:
On the right side, the different shaded boxes indicate whether the processor is busy or waiting due to some reason ( ICache/Dcache miss etc. ). \xA0If a 'processor busy' is defined as a state where the processor is executing an instruction, then all the other boxes should indicate that the processor is Idle due to some reason. The 'short int, long int , short fp and long fp' do NOT seem to indicate causes that would make the processor wait. \xA0 So it is not clear to me as to why these are classified separately - a short int operation could have been classifies as a 'processor busy itself'. \xA0 Further these operations seem to be taking a significant percentage of the Issue cycles for the different programs. \xA0 \xA0If the short int constitutes a Valid instruction execution, then one can deduce that the processor is busy for a larger percentage of time than indicated.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The original paper the graph is from, which is cited on the slide, explains 'processor busy represents utilized issue slots; all others represent wasted cycles' \xA0I think short int, long int, short fp, and long fp may be due to data hazards, i.e. an issue slot could not be used because instructions were waiting on results from a short int, long int, short fp, or long fp instruction. \xA0I am not positive about this, but the main takeaway is that many functional units are underutilized in a superscalar processor. \xA0It is essentially motivating multithreading by saying many functional units are under utilized and switching in other threads on stalls could hide some of this latency.

Hi Yadav-\xA0 Initial question was 'why can't we use non blocking when TLB miss upon a load instruction'?. I think the answer is that if TLB misses, you don't know when o.s or h/w will walk the page tables, whether you will end up w/ a page fault that will cause an exception. Under these circumstances, if you do non-blocking you may end up w/ instructions that will have been committed while an earlier instruction ( the one that caused the TLB miss) will be the source of the page fault exception. A TLB miss occurs because the page entry is not present, hence the MMU needs to access the physical memory (where the page tables reside) and retrieves the missing entry. Once this is done, the instruction re-execute and causes a data miss again and the TLB this time hits, a virtual to physical translation is being executed and cache block retrieved from physical memory and brought back into cache. Of course, you can have an early re-start so the processor can resume execution. However until then, the CPU is stalled.

I think it is possible to not stall the processor until the operand that caused the TLB miss to occur is used, as long as there is a hardware page table walker. \xA0If the page table walk is performed in software, this means there is a vector to a different PC in the OS to fetch the page table from memory and fill in the TLB. \xA0Thus, you cannot continue executing the program that faulted. \xA0However, in a hardware page table walker, you could have the page table walker operating concurrently as you continue executing instructions from the faulting program. \xA0 However, the complexity in doing this may be rather high, and since page faults are supposed to be rare anyways, this may not improve performance significantly in the end. \xA0The tradeoff might not be worth it.

Hi Yadav-\xA0 Initial question was 'why can't we use non blocking when TLB miss upon a load instruction'?. I think the answer is that if TLB misses, you don't know when o.s or h/w will walk the page tables, whether you will end up w/ a page fault that will cause an exception. Under these circumstances, if you do non-blocking you may end up w/ instructions that will have been committed while an earlier instruction ( the one that caused the TLB miss) will be the source of the page fault exception. A TLB miss occurs because the page entry is not present, hence the MMU needs to access the physical memory (where the page tables reside) and retrieves the missing entry. Once this is done, the instruction re-execute and causes a data miss again and the TLB this time hits, a virtual to physical translation is being executed and cache block retrieved from physical memory and brought back into cache. Of course, you can have an early re-start so the processor can resume execution. However until then, the CPU is stalled.

I think it is possible to not stall the processor until the operand that caused the TLB miss to occur is used, as long as there is a hardware page table walker. \xA0If the page table walk is performed in software, this means there is a vector to a different PC in the OS to fetch the page table from memory and fill in the TLB. \xA0Thus, you cannot continue executing the program that faulted. \xA0However, in a hardware page table walker, you could have the page table walker operating concurrently as you continue executing instructions from the faulting program. \xA0 However, the complexity in doing this may be rather high, and since page faults are supposed to be rare anyways, this may not improve performance significantly in the end. \xA0The tradeoff might not be worth it.
